PICTURE CREDITS
Other than as indicated in the captions themselves

Cover illustration, Richard M. Smith; pp. 5, 23, C. Hogarth, Portraits of Famous
People (Dover Publications, N. Y., 1994); pp. 12, 35, 216, 263, 303, J.G. Heck, Heck’s
Pictorial Archive of Art and Architecture (Dover Publications, N. Y., 1994); p. 38, V.
Hanlon, Jewish Motifs and Illustrations (Dover Publications, N. Y., 1991); pp. 46, 47,
255, C. B. Grafton, Egyptian Designs (Dover Publications, N. Y., 1993); p. 139, T.
Tierney, Historic Costume From Ancient Times to the Renaissance (Dover
Publications, N. Y., 2003); p. 142, J. Harter, Animals (Dover Publications, N. Y.,
1979); pp. 218, 272, T. Tierney, Ancient Egyptian Fashions (Dover Publications, N. Y.,
1999); p. 257, J. Green, Life in Ancient Egypt (Dover Publications, N. Y., 1989); p. 258,
Y.S. Green, Life in Ancient Polynesia (Dover Publications, N. Y., 2001); pp. 279, 312,
S. K. Lothrop, Pre-Columbian Designs from Panama (Dover Publications, N. Y.,
1976); pp. 287, 288, 304, M. Noble, Dragons: A Book of Designs (Dover Publications,
N. Y., 2002); p. 296, P. F. Copeland, North American Indian Dances and Rituals
(Dover Publications, N. Y., 1997).

To the author’s knowledge, all other illustrations contained in this work are either
copyright free or in the public domain. However, if we have inadvertently trespassed on
anyone’s copyright in this respect, we will dutifully make the required amends and
ensure that proper credit is given in future editions.

353

ABOUT THE AUTHOR
Dwardu Cardona was born, raised, and educated in Malta, Europe, from where he emigrated
to Canada in 1959. Less than a year later, in mid-1960, he became involved in the study of
catastrophism and the reconstruction of the Solar System’s cosmic history. He has since then
acted as a Contributing Editor for KRONOS (1975-1978) and, later, as a Senior Editor for the
same periodical (1979-1988) and, later still, as the Editor for AEON (1995-2006). He was
one of the Founding Fathers behind the Canadian Society for Interdisciplinary Studies (now
defunct), and has acted as a consultant on mythology and cosmogony for Chronology and
Catastrophism Review, the official organ of the British-based Society for Interdisciplinary
Studies. He has also acted as the Editor for the Osiris Series of books sponsored by Cosmos
& Chronos.
As a writer, Cardona has now published well over a hundred articles in various periodicals,
most of them on the subject that is covered in more detail in his present series of books: God
Star (2006), Flare Star (2007), and Primordial Star (2009), which actually form the prequels
to the present work.
He has additionally lectured at the University of Bergamo, in Italy, and at various
organizations in England, Canada, and the United States.
He presently makes his home together with his wife in Vancouver, British Columbia,
Canada.
354
